direction.raw_text: Sounds of the innerspaces rushing forward. Then a splinter of blue light in the center of the picture. It breaks wide, showing the top and bottom a silhouetted curtain of razor sharp teeth suggesting that we are inside of a tremendous gullet, looking out at the onrushing undersea world at night. HEAR a symphony of underwater sounds: landslide, metabolic sounds, the rare and secret noises that certain undersea species share with each other. Also, the hint of familiar music, twisted and distorted by the depths.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a pleasant, moonlit, windless night in mid-June. We see a long straight stretch of white beach. Behind the low dunes are the dark shapes of large expensive houses. Hear a number of voices singing. It sounds like an eastern university's alma mater, no longer distorted.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: BEACH NIGHT SHARK'S POINT OF VIEW RISING OUT OF THE WATER, LOOKING AT

direction.raw_text: . BEACH  NIGHT  ANOTHER ANGLE Around a blazing bonfire, a group of young men and women, beer cans (or maybe a keg) in evidence, as well as the bota Spanish leather wine-bag much in favor by beach and ski-bum types. The group is swapping sentimental alma maters, weepily singing eastern Ivy League anthems - Dartmouth, Cornell, Harvard, Penn, etc. Two young people break away from the others. They are Tom Cassidy and Chrissie. Behind them, there is considerable necking activity; Tom and Chrissie are more serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Makes a clumsy attempt at snaring Chrissie, cups her from behind. She squirms playfully out of his grasp. We discover he's not especially sober.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! Hey hey! I'm with you, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.ToD: ANOTHER PART OF THE BEACH NIGHT
result.heading: ANOTHER PART OF THE BEACH NIGHT

direction.raw_text: . ANOTHER PART OF THE BEACH  NIGHT Tom and Chrissie are separated from the others, silhouetted against the fire, she pauses and looks at the ocean, he is plodding along in the sand, winded. Chrissie runs down the slope of the dune towards the water, leaving Tom reeling atop the dune. As she runs, she is shedding her clothes. Tom is trying to trail her by her clothes, like Hansel following bread crumbs through the woods. But Chrissie is way ahead of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She runs headlong into the inviting sea, plunges cleanly into the water with a light "Whoops!" as the cold water sweeps over her. Behind all this, we continue to hear the sentimental, beery chorus of alma maters. Then we see it -- a gentle bulge in the water, a ripple that passes her a dozen feet away. A pressure wave lifts her up, then eases her down again, like a smooth, sudden swell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks around for him, finds him still on the beach, his feet tangled in his pants, which have dropped around his ankles. She starts to swim back in to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tommy? Don't dunk me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Her expression freezes. The water-bulge is racing towards her. The first bump jolts her upright, out of the water to her hips. She reaches under water to touch her leg. Whatever she feels makes her open her mouth to scream, but she is slammed again, hard, whipped into an arc of about eight feet, up and down, submerging her down to her open mouth, choking off any scream she might try to make. Another jolt to her body, driving her under so that only her hair swirls on the surface. Then it too is sucked below in a final and terrible jerking motion. HOLD on the eddies and swirls until we're sure it's all over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE ON TOM ON BEACH In his shorts, laughing to himself, turning in slow stoned circles, held prisoner by his windbreaker which seems to have him in an armlock, as he struggles to free his arm from a tight sleeve. As he turns, we hear the alma maters in the background, from the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A shaft of morning sun blasts through the crack between the bottom of the shade and the windowsill, falling across the heads of the sleeping couple on the bed. It catches Martin Brody right across the eyes, bringing him up from sleep. The job is completed by the clock radio, which clicks on with local fisherman's report and weather.

direction.raw_text: Ellen Brody burrows her head under the covers, avoiding morning for a few precious minutes more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear the scampering toenails of two cocker spaniels scrabbling around the foot of the bed. Brody swings out of bed, wearing shorts, socks, and tee shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leads the dogs out of the bedroom and down to the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Hayes Landing reports conditions good, with stripers and jacks. The Coast Guard has no storm warning from Block Island to Cape Hatteras; a light chop with freshening winds, continued clear and mild... (etc.)

direction.raw_text: Brody enters, sets down some dog food, goes to make coffee, starts to fill kettle to boil water, the cold water rushes through and out the burnt-out bottom of the kettle.

direction.raw_text: Ellen Brody, a tall, attractive blonde woman, enters from upstairs. She's still slightly sleepy, not what you'd call an "Instant-On" person. Mornings are not her best time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before Brody can answer, Michael, his oldest boy, enters, holding his hand. There is bright new blood on it, but he is sensibly unconcerned. It's a normal childhood scrape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael goes on out and upstairs. Ellen fumbles in her pocket and produces Brody's new glasses, which she holds out to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody reacts to this, and bends to kiss her lightly. Then more seriously.

direction.raw_text: He looks out the window to the view beyond, discovering some new wonder in the fresh sunlit morning.

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be silly - You're going to make summer better for them...

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Older, sillier.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as he goes to make coffee, he fumbles with the new glasses) I don't want to depend on these things, y'know - sometimes you can weaken your eyes.

direction.raw_text: Sean, the younger child, is happily romping in the summer air, enjoying the very air he breathes.

direction.raw_text: Martin Brody's Country Squire police wagon rushes past, taking the view to an enormous billboard depicting a typical summer day in Amity. A beautiful model splashes in the gold surf, languishing in a Solarcaine sun. AMITY WELCOMES YOU is written above her flailing arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three small figures in the landscape, walking the beach. The surf is rough and there is sea-floor debris strewn about from the receding tide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE Deputy Hendricks is searching the shore about one hundred yards down wind. Meanwhile, Brody, in his casual police attire, and Tom Cassidy, still in the clothing we saw him in last night, walk down the beach. Brody fingers the missing girl's shoes, purse and clothes. In the daylight, Cassidy misconducts himself, wavering between inflated maturity and tear-blown adolescence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A shrill whistle makes them turn. Hendricks is fifty yards away, on his knees. He blows again, a feeble report this time.

direction.raw_text: A skein of seaweed garnishes the base of this isolated dune. The booming waves and fizzing surf make dialogue inaudible. Deputy Hendricks on hands and knees, looking white as a sheet. Brody tells Cassidy to wait at the foot of the dune, and ventures up. Hendricks stops him with a wave-off, saying something at the same time. Brody nods understanding and steps up cautiously and looks down. He adjusts his glasses, trying to make sense of what he is looking at. Whatever he sees has a marked effect on his entire physique. Kicking out with his foot, Brody sends dozens of angry horseshoe crabs into an escape frenzy and they boil over the top of the dune and down its slopes. Cassidy takes a few uneasy steps backwards when Brody waves him over. He shakes his head. An awkward moment. Then Cassidy shuffles forward and up the few remaining feet, his eyes looking everywhere but down. Brody says something else and Cassidy shakes his head again, eyes out at sea. Brody puts his hand gently around the quaking man's shoulder. Nodding, he starts to look down, an inch at a time. He looks. He, too, can't make out what it is at first. Then he understands. The jolt that assaults Cassidy is not unexpected. He falls backward in a sitting position as though shot. Nods yes -- it's her. Brody turns and slides off the dune, stumbling close. Hear his breathing. He looks around, envisioning the week ahead of him....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chrissie's remains, incomplete from the chest down, horribly bitten. (NOTE: See Hooper's dialog in Sc. 91 for complete description of corpse.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody walks through the door and enters his office, holding a fizzing glass of Alka-Seltzer. Polly, his sixty-one year old secretary follows close on his heels with her shorthand pad of messages and reminders. In the outer office, Hendricks and Cassidy slump into chairs, sipping from fizzing dixie cups. Brody dips into file drawers for the appropriate forms. He gently turns on Polly, who is behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody slips behind his typewriter, putting paper in the machine with the effortless ease of years of practice. He's obviously no stranger to paperwork. He touch types, hardly ever looking down, checking his notes and listening with one ear to Polly. He is affected by what he's seen, but there's work to be done.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If this is going to work, you've got to keep current stuff out here, and put 'closed' files in there. The 'Pendings' stay on my desk, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is in no order of importance, Chief: There's a meeting on the Amity Town Council on Aging this Monday night, Bentoncourt Hall. The Fire Inspector wants you to go over the fireworks site with him before he catches the one o'clock ferry. Mainly, you have a batch of calls about that new Karate school.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brody has just typed the girl's name. He skips the space for Cause-of-Death, and just under it types the Next-of-Kin information he has collected from her wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The phone rings and Polly picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody nestles the phone between ear and collar, listening, as he turns to the typewriter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Searle's Rent-a-Bike, the Rainy Ale, Tisberry's Hardware... they say it's those nine-year-olds from the school practicing karate on all those nice picket fences.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, Santos.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: leans forward, staring at what he just wrote. Polly cocks her head and removes the phone from his ear.

direction.raw_text: Brody takes a breath. A new resolve comes over him.

dialogue.raw_text: Glad I caught you. There's a city truck with New Hampshire plates parked right in front of my...

direction.raw_text: . AMITY MAIN STREET  DAY In the busy center of a town preparing for the big Fourth of July weekend, Brody wends his way around sidewalk activity, purpose and haste in each stride. As he turns a corner a little man in a white smock emerges from the Funeral Parlor. This is Carl Santos, Amity's part-time coroner. Santos looks both ways before crossing Colonial Drive. Brody passes Keisel's Bicycle Rental, navigating an awkward course through an odd assortment of Schwinns that line the sidewalk in front of a demolished white picket fence. Keisel intercepts Brody on the run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody nods yes, and starts to move away, but Keisel holds on to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds up bicycle. The bicycle's spokes are bent and broken from some sort of blows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (he stares at Brody's face) Wait-a-minute. (stares some more) Glasses, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at those fences! Little guys about eight to ten years old. And look at this!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They did that with their bare hands.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call me later in the day, okay, Harry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - PORCH Santos emerges with Ben Meadows, the stylish, late-thirties editor of the Amity Gazette. Together they cut a beeline for the other side of the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Past taverns and chowder shacks, past bleacher construction and July Fourth posters, Brody enters Hardware and Sporting Goods... so overstocked that beach umbrellas, aluminum deck chairs, and rainbow beach towels splash a surplus of color from the display window to the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HARDWARE STORE  DAY The store proprietor is busy at work on an inventory list with a mainland delivery man.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stuff's no good to me in August when the Pilgrims come in June... (to Brody) Go on and help yourself to whatever you need, Chief. Can you work the register?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brody emerges with enough poster-board, wooden stakes, nails, paint, and brushes to close every beach on the island. He starts back the way he came when Hendricks shoots up the street in the patrol jeep. He stops fast enough to call attention, leans out the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Polly told me to tell you there's a scout troop in Avril Bay doing the mile swim for their Merit Badges. I couldn't call them in, there's no phone out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hands him the sign material) Get out of there  take these back to the office and make up some 'Beach Closed' signs, and let Polly do the printing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter with my printing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . VAUGHN'S REALTY  DAY Revealing Larry Vaughn, the Mayor of Amity, exchanging anxieties with Ben Meadows and Coroner Santos and two other city Selectmen. They come out in a group, reach the sunlight, and squint down the street as Brody careens around the corner and out of sight. Deputy Hendricks, laden with his arts and crafts, passes them on the street front.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn and group exchange horrified looks, but we get the impression it is not in response to the shark-attack news.

direction.raw_text: They all crowd into a Cadillac El Dorado with Vaughn Realty signs on the doors.

dialogue.raw_text: What have you got there, Lenny?

dialogue.raw_text: Who've you told this to, Lenny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just found out about it -- but there's a bunch of Boy Scouts in the water a coupla miles down the coast from where we found the girl. Avril Bay, thereabouts. Chief went to dry them off.

dialogue.raw_text: (to Meadows) Take my car, okay? (to Hendricks) You come with us, Lenny.

dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A flotilla of twenty exhausted Boy Scouts round a buoy that marks the official course. A rowboat with Scoutmaster using a bullhorn keeps pace, and urges the boys on.

dialogue.raw_text: (bullhorn effect) Let's go, Robbie. You too, Hofner. Boyle, keep your head up. Alberts, keep kicking... (etc., ad lib)

direction.raw_text: Two older Seascouts look on with stop watches and clipboards, while some Parents shade their eyes from the sun, watching their offspring. Brody pulls up in the Amity Police jeep, and starts toward the people. Behind him, Vaughn's Cadillac pulls up and skids to a stop. In it are Vaughn, Meadows, the Doctor, maybe a Selectman, and Hendricks, with his arms still full of sign material. Vaughn intercepts Brody, the others circle around him, effectively slowing his progress through the sand to the scouts.

direction.raw_text: The men all laugh, ad lib their remembrances of this foolishness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody looks out to the water where the scouts are rounding another buoy on the home stretch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn indicates the beach where the Scouts are flopping out onto the sand, exhausted, glad to be finished.

direction.raw_text: All ad lib agreement.

direction.raw_text: The others surround Brody as Vaughn leads the way back to the cars, ad libbing their problem with the little karate choppers. Hendricks puts the signs back into the trunk of Vaughn's Cadillac. Vaughn waves casually to the Scouts and swimmers who are vigorously toweling off in the background.
direction.name: direction

location: ON THE BEACH AT AVRIL BAY

dialogue.raw_text: Martin! (he catches up with him) Are you going to shut down the beach on your own authority?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do I need any more authority?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Technically, you need the instruction of a civic ordinance, or a special meeting of the town selectmen...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the good guy) That's just going by the book. We're just a little anxious that you're rushing into something serious here. This is your first summer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now tell me something I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I'm saying is that Amity is a summer town -- we need summer dollars, and if they can't swim here, they'll use the beaches at Cape Cod, or Long Island.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So we should set out a smorgasbord?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're not even sure what it was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What else could've done that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Doctor) Boat propeller?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think, possibly... sure. A boating accident.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some weekend tramp accidentally goes swimming too far, she's a little drunk, a fishing boat comes along -- MEADOWS Remember when Fred Ganz went scalloping in his BVD's? He was going to swim to New Bedford, he said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and Bill Mayhew almost caught him in his net...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting the merriment) Doctor, you're the one who told me what it was!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was wrong. We'll have to amend the report.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We never had that kind of trouble here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think you can appreciate the gut reaction people have to these things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was only reacting to what I was told.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking Brody aside) It's all psychological, anyway. You yell 'Barracuda' and everyone says 'huh'. You yell 'Shark' and we've got a panic on our hands. I think we all agree we don't need a panic this close to the 4th of July.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't work in a vacuum. Why don't you make Hendricks Chief? His family's been here since the Puritans -- half this island are his cousins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Martin, we hired the best man we could find.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We need someone who isn't prejudiced by old feuds or family ties, someone who can referee things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have our complete support.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now then. We've got a vandalism problem we ought to talk about...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In front of Amity's only Music Store, a battered old pick-up truck pulls in to the curb. Quint and his mate cross silently heading into the music store.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A gently tinkling bell tolls Quint's entrance. Inside the store, a ten-year-old boy is being shown a clarinet. He is playing a mellow low tone, and running "Ode to Joy." Quint looms past him like Neptune rising from the deep, and lets his hand drop on the counter with a slap that sounds like a club on flesh. The Shopkeeper abandons the little boy and meets Quint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Without waiting for it to be wrapped, he picks up the gleaming wire in his gnarled fist, and drops a bill on the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No answer from Quint, who stops and sings along with the boy. The little kid's music degenerates into a series of awkward squeaks and blurps, as Quint stares at him. Quint continues out the door, threading his way through the people in the street like some great fish. As he gets up into the cab of his pick-up, its door swings open so we can see a crude stylized shark decorating its side. It slams behind him as Quint gets in and drives away.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE COUNTY COURTHOUSE AND COUNTY OFFICES

direction.raw_text: - THE COUNTY COURTHOUSE AND COUNTY OFFICES - DAY We are looking at the closed double white front doors of the building, through which we can hear a rolling boil of agitated conversation. After a beat, they open to reveal Mrs. Kintner, looking as though she has been visited by the wrath of God; in effect, she has. Her eyes are puffy and swollen from weeping, her clothing is put on and fastened awkwardly, her gait is not normal. As she walks toward us, Quint enters with his back to us, they pass without notice; Mrs. Kintner moving out of sight, Quint leading us through the doors into the town hall.

The Amity Pier area is a minor madhouse: out-of-state cars elbow local vehicles for parking space at the foot of the dock, and a parade of bounty-hunting townspeople, islanders, off-islanders, tourist, and others shout and push their way onto the crowded pier, each carrying some bizarre or appropriate tool for the real or imagined capture of an unarmed shark of indeterminate size. Rods and reels, drop lines, crossbows, slingshots, harpoons, shotguns, rifles, nets and tridents; every fishing supply store and sporting goods house within a hundred miles has been cannibalized to equip this weird array.

dialogue.raw_text: Might give it a try. That three thousand bounty beats working for a living. (yells to his Mate) We ready?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BY A particularly awkward moment between a small sailboat and a couple of powerboats. The sailboat is trying to hoist sail to make it away from the pier under sail, a real yachtsman's conceit, since Hornblower himself probably couldn't navigate through this mess. Brody, a landlubber for sure, is trying to direct traffic to untangle this new mess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amidst all this, we can hear the angry shouts of the entangled crews.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody starts back towards the shore, Hooper is by his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before he can finish, Brody spots something on shore that moves him to shout to his deputy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody looks, and stops by a boat that's about to cast off. He holds out his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man passes Brody a cigar box filled with dynamite sticks. Brody tucks the dynamite under his arm, and continues down the pier. Hooper is still with him. All around them are two distinctly different breeds; the quiet pros, like Ben Gardner, in well-worn, comfortable clothes, with efficient, sensible gear, and the amateur crazies, with all manner of weapons and impractical, silly tourist clothing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Just back up! No, the other way! Cut it to your left! Your other left! The big boat, your front end is out way too far. Little boat, stay still!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dammit, a vessel under sail has the right of way!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You schmuck, you ain't under sail, you're goddam drifting!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stepping in to help) Ahoy, sail! You got an oar? Well, scull it out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell that stinkpotter to belay!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell that ragsetter I'm going to poke him in the snoot!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just cast off in turn and make for the channel, OK?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, I wonder if you could tell me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (noticing something) Is that dynamite?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If that's dynamite, give it here, or don't leave port.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aw, c'mon, it's just fireworks. Sharks like fireworks, it attracts them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hand it over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brody is on the phone, talking to his office, trying to get Hendricks' attention. He throws a handful of washers at the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There's a fantail launch out there that won't make it beyond the breakwater.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're tellin' me. I swear, this town has gone crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Officer, I wonder if you could tell me where I could find Chief Brody?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hooper, Matt Hooper. From the Oceanographic Institute. (holds out his hand)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - OCEAN - DAY Ben Gardner's boat is in the lead with Gardner's shouting derisive comments at the crowd headed out from land. The armada is spread out and moving in a ragged circle, fifteen boats in all. One man heaves cherry bombs into the water. A smaller boat going in the opposite direction offers us Barwood, forking spaghetti leftovers into the ocean while his friend pours out a bottle of ketchup. A speedboat chugs by, one of the occupants reading instructions aloud from a book entitled "Sharks - East Coast, Vol. I." boatload of impoverished scallop fishermen throw a net overboard, full of gaps and split ends. The professionals look professional, but the landlubbers out for the $3000 make it impossible for everybody. Collisions are barely averted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Out-of-Towner in a small boat is bent over in a life and death struggle, his rod in a tight arc. His buddy leaps across to lend a hand. Twenty yards away in another boat the same struggle ensues. This time it's the overloaded boat with the poor scallop fishermen. Shouts of I'M ON! DIG IN! STRIKE! Then a tangle of tackle springs from the water. They have hooked each other. Joy turns to swearing.  Arnold Felix stands up to applaud the mishap, while his buddy Pratt takes careful aim with his Remington 1100 12-gauge and blasts at the tackle as if it were a clay pigeon.  The tangle explodes -- Both the Out-of-Towners and the Scallop Fisherman falls over backward -- ANGLE - HARRY'S BOAT Three men are aboard, one holding a rod which holds a fast arc. A few yards off stern we see a triangular dorsal fin crossing back and forth, struggling, jerking, the mighty tail threshing. One man is screaming success, the other two slapping the angler on the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They spot it and sour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The owner of Pratt's boat throws it forward and Pratt removes a .45 automatic from the holster of his belt. He tests it, firing once in the air. As they near the scene of the struggle, eleven other boats begin converging, until -- HARRY'S BOAT Everyone wants to get into the act. They are attacking the threshing beast with all they've got. Pratt uses his automatic, another blasts point blank with a shotgun. There are occasional water ricochets and the bounty hunters duck from time to time as bullets skip by. Finally, the shark stops threshing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, get over there! He ain't caught it yet!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Their boat has moved close to the shark, closer than Harry's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of his party in the over-filled boat grabs a gaff and leans out to grab the moribund shark. But Harry won't give up the line, still reeling in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pratt nods reluctantly. The man swings, lodges the gaff and hauls the shark up onto the gunwale. A paroxysm of cheers from the surrounding boats. Smoke flares are fired into the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a ten-foot tiger, and what a mess -- splattered with bullet punctures, gashes, bleeding from several orifices. But it is not dead -- it kicks back to life and threatens to capsize the boat. Pratt panics and fires six times with his .45. The bullets pierce the shark's head, pass through, and split the fiberglass hull through which a flood of water rises. Everybody stands up as the boat slips beneath them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (exultant) Hand me that pole! Quick!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Beat it! I hooked him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's the family, Harry? (to the man with gaff) Go on and do it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We split down the middle?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a tug-of-war) Let go my shark!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Amity Morgue is also the Amity Funeral Home, a Victorian house that normally serves as the community's mortuary. The Coroner, a professional small-town GP, is standing by as Hooper is speaking into a sophisticated cassette recorder with a headpiece that leaves his hands free for measurement with a calibrator or calipers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a shrug, the Coroner slides open the drawer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's show Mr. Hooper our accident.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He is looking down as the drawer slides past him, still matter- of-fact, turning on his recorder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sheet has just been lifted, and Hooper stares down at the lump on the slab. He stops, turns off his recorder as emotions wage war with his senses. Rationality wins, and he turns on the recorder again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Victim One, identified as Christine Watkins, female Caucasian...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...height and weight may only be estimated from partial remains. Torso severed in mid-thorax, eviscerated with no major organs remaining. May I have a drink of water? Right arm severed above the elbow with massive tissue loss from upper musculature. Portions of denuded bone remaining. (tense, to Brody)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: did you notify the coast guard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it was local jurisdiction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Left arm, head, shoulders, sternum and portions of ribcage intact. (to Brody) Please don't smoke. With minor post- mortem lacerations and abrasions. Bite marks indicate typical non-frenzy feeding pattern of large squali, possibly carchaninus lonimanus, or isurus glaucas. Gross tissue loss and post-mortem erosion of bite surfaces prevent detailed analysis; however, teeth and jaws of the attacking squali must be considered above average for these waters. (to Brody again)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you go out in a boat and look around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, we just checked the beach...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turns off the recorder) It wasn't an 'accident,' it wasn't a boat propeller, or a coral reef, or Jack the Ripper. It was a shark. It was a shark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We open close on ugly, open shark's jaws, still oozing blood and gore. As the shark is hoisted up into the air on a gin- pole hoist dockside, Meadows is seen passing with his secretary and a photographer from the Amity Gazette. A crowd of returning fishermen from the Armada and townspeople are gathering around the fish as it is hoisted tail-up into the classic sports fisherman's trophy shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he and the photographer turn to mob, we see Hooper and Brody arriving from the morgue. Hooper immediately heads towards the shark, while Brody pauses and we see a look of relief and delight cross his features.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Men ad lib "No, I caught it..." "I hooked him," etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He continues to call directions and move people out of the way to set up his shot. Hooper is measuring the shark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The men (Felix, Pratt, et al) get Brody to join them in the shot. The whole town and the Armada fishermen all line up in a classic "high school" graduating class shot with the victorious fishermen kneeling in front, and the rest of the Armada and Townspeople arranged behind them. Hendricks hold up the "Beach Closed" sign in ironic victory.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ginny, get this out on the state wire to AP and UPI in Boston and New York. Have one of them pick it up for the national and call Dave Axelrod in New York and tell him this is from me and he owes me one... let's get a picture.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if one man can catch a fish in 50 days, then I guess 50 of these bozos can catch a fish in one day -- beginner's luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (crossing to men around shark) You did it! Did Ben Gardner catch this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, everybody, I want to get a picture for the paper -- could everyone clear out of the way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could you get out of the shot, young man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who, me? Okay... (he drifts off)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: SHOWING VAUGHN APPROACHING THE DOCK Brody spots the Mayor coming towards the dock, and detaches himself from the group to join him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Larry, if you'd see these clowns leave, you'd never believe they'd come back with anything. But they got him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's good. That's real good. Ben Meadows getting pictures for the paper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The men who landed the monster are in a tight cluster, debating something with Hooper, who is dwarfed by the big beer bellies and ham-fisted hands all around him. It's probable we don't even see him. The Men ad lib "What kind of shark is this?" "It's a shark like in the movies they got sharks." "It's a man-eater, for sure." "I bet it's a record-breaker," etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooper enters the circle, and picks up where he left off, measuring the shark's teeth. Others watch him. Charlie and Denherder walk over to the shark. Charlie punches it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) It's a tiger shark. Very rare in these waters, and definitely a maneater.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They are walking down to the shark together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody and Vaughn are by now near the circle of fishermen, who are surrounding Hooper, raising their voices at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Felix, Pratt and the others ad lib disagreement. "You're not gonna cut up my trophy," etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Mrs. Kintner approaching, dressed in black.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who's that young man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Matt Hooper, the specialist they send down from the Oceanographic Institute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (speaking to everyone) I think we all owe a debt of gratitude to these men for catching this monster.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whadya mean, 'Bite Radius?' What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Teeth are teeth, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't say this wasn't the shark, I just said I wasn't sure this was the one...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What d'ya mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are hundreds of different kinds of sharks; makos, blues, hammerheads, white-tips... any one of them could've attacked. Look -- shark digestion is slow. We could open this one up, and find whatever he's been eating is still inside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's disgusting! This is the largest, meanest, most vicious shark ever landed off Amity Island, and a known maneater!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's just cut him open and see what's inside...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not, Larry? We could get a positive confirmation that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be reasonable, boys -- this isn't the time or the place to do some kind of half-assed autopsy on a fish. Ben... (to Meadows) do you have all the pictures you need?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Plenty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (seeing something offstage, with low intensity) I am not going to stand here and watch this fish cut open and see some kid fall out on the dock. Besides... (he indicates off)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Brody) Chief, I'll take responsibility for this. Boys, cut this ugly sonofabitch down before he stinks up the whole island. Harve, tomorrow you and Carl take him out and dump him right in the drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . KINTNER JOINS THE GROUP She seeks out Brody, and stops in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods, she slaps him full across the face. There is an embarrassed silence. Some people leave, following a trend that began with the first mention of cutting open the shark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops, unable to continue. Her father takes her arm and leads her away. Pratt, Harry and the others trail off after her. During the rest of the scene, the camera tightens in on Brody to the exclusion of the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before Hooper can finish, Brody's shoulders slump and he goes slack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and leaves abruptly, surrendering the dock to Vaughn and Hooper, who eye each other with mutual dis-admiration.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . KINTNER Chief Brody?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . KINTNER My Alex was a beautiful little boy and you killed him. Did you know that? You knew there was a shark out there. You knew a girl got killed here last week. I just found that out. But you knew. You knew it was dangerous, but you let people go swimming anyway. You knew all those things, and still my boy is dead now and there's nothing you can do about that. My boy is dead. I wanted you to know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, Martin. She's in a sick, terrible state.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, maybe this is the wrong time to pursue this, but I'm not sure...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost to himself) She's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's all get out of here, this place stinks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - DINING ROOM Brody and Ellen, Sean and Michael, have all finished dinner. Brody's plate is untouched, a virgin meatloaf. His glass, on the other hand, is well used, with the remnants of a stiff scotch and ice. He is staring across the table at the youngest, Sean, who makes a face at him. He makes a face back. They play this game together for a few minutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean gives Daddy the kiss. Brody shoos him and Michael off to bed. Ellen, who is feeling progressively more left out with each passing moment, gets up abruptly and clears a few dishes. Brody is not letting her into his world for the moment, and it shows. There's a knock at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ellen opens the door for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooper enters. He's carrying a couple of bottles of wine which he picked up in town. He sits down near Brody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts in on it, as soon as someone has indicated "go ahead."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They exchange a long look that evolves into a slightly desperate, but shared laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They laugh some more. Ellen is again left out of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody begins stripping the foil off the wine, screwing in a corkscrew, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody has the cork out of the wine. Pop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody takes the fine wine, and pours it into his drink glass filling the tumbler to the top with ice cubes, diluted scotch, and the wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He extends the bottle to Hooper, who politely accepts a token sip. He takes some for himself, and offers some to Ellen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody digests all this; confirmation of facts he has gleaned in his newly acquired knowledge of the shark species. There is a long pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gets up and they both start out. Ellen watches them go.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: C'mere and give Daddy a kiss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because he needs it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Martin Brody residence?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi. I'm Matt Hooper. If your husband is here, I'd like to talk to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So would I. Come on in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you like something? Some coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (seeing Brody's plate) Is anyone having this...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dynamite! (to Brody) How was your day...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Swell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (producing wine) Here... one red, one white.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (boning his fish) Ummm. Really good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My husband tells me you're in sharks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't put it that way. But I love sharks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You love sharks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do. (he tells a story about his boyhood and a shark) But you've still got a problem here, there's a shark just off the island somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How come you have to tell them that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, but what are you talking about? Didn't they catch the shark this afternoon? It was on the Cape station news.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They caught a shark, not the shark. Big difference. I could've proved it this afternoon, by cutting that one open and examining his stomach contents. Also, his bite was too small.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was lucky to find that in town -- it's an estate bottled vintage year...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as Brody pours) We ought to let it breathe... Whatever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's all have a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You too, sweetheart...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (toasting) Here's to your husband, the only other rational man on the island. Day after tomorrow, I'll be gone, and he'll be the only one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're leaving?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Going out on the 'Aurora.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that a boat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it! The best-funded research expedition to ever study the shark... around the world in 18 months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like those Cousteau specials on television? I think it's for the kids, but I love them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better than Cousteau, or Compagno with computers, telemetry, Defense Department funding...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw a show with sea otters, and a big turtle... Mikey loved it. Made me promise to get him one. Will you live on the boat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Martin hates boats. Hates the water. On the ferry to the mainland, he sits in the car the whole way over. He's got this childhood thing, there's a clinical word for it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Drowning. Lemme ask you something. Is it true most attacks take place in three feet of water, around 10 feet from the beach?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Like the kid on your beach. I wish I could've examined that shark they caught...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something else. Do most attacks go unreported?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About half of them. A lot of 'missing swimmers' are really shark victims.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a kind of a lone shark, called, uh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rogue?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Rogue. Picks out an area where there's food and hangs out there as long as the food supply lasts?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's called Territoriality. It's a theory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And before 1900, when people first starting swimming for recreation, before public bathing and resorts, there were very few shark attacks, cause sharks didn't know what they were missing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could say that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't we have one more drink, you and I, and then we go down and cut open that old shark and see for sure what's inside him, or not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you do that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am Chief of Police. I can do anything I want. (to Hooper) You want to come?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm flattered you should ask.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dark, spooky shed, with shadows of boats and strange silhouettes of boat parts and scaffolding. At one end, the large, symmetrical bulk of the shark's carcass lies on a tarp. A single dark figure is bending over the dead shark. The large double doors at one end of the shed squeak open, and the Shadowy Figure moves abruptly away from the shark. The new entrants move into the shed. It is Hooper and Brody and they are continuing the conversation begun in the car on the way over. As the Shadowy Figure moves silently into a vantage point against one wall, he passes through the light from a window; it is Quint, and we only see him long enough to recognize him as he backs against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They bend over the shape like 18th century graverobbers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear a slurp and a squish as Hooper produces a big knife and dips into the shark with a major incision.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From his vantage point, Quint watches, unseen by the two men. Brody is holding the light, fighting the gag reflex, fascinated by the bizarre ritual.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He kicks the remains around below camera.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...And it was Dartmouth Winter weekend, and she was Homecoming Queen, and I was her date; then she got into the fact that her family had more money than my family, and she was right -- her great-grandfather was in mining, and my ancestors were Yankee shipbuilders. So we broke up and I went home with some beatnik from Sarah Lawrence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What stinks so bad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our friend, the shark.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We always had a summer place on the water -- Newport, the Vineyard, so I figured I'd major in something I knew about. Oceanography, marine biology. It was that, or design racing yachts like my older brother. Hmmm. He we go. Up the old alimentary canal. Hold the light.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We open the abdominal cavity and check the digestive tract. Simple. (he attends to his work)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Half a flounder. Hmmm... a burlap bag... a paint can... aha!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? What?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just as I thought. He drifted up here with the Gulf Stream, from southern waters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can you tell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (showing it) Florida license plate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He ate a car?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) No, but Tiger sharks are the garbage cans of the ocean. They eat anything. But this one didn't eat any people. There's nothing here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do we do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're looking for a shark, you don't look on land. You go out and chum for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Chum?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only one sure way to find him -- offer him a little something to eat. Chum -- blood, waste meat, fish, anything. They can sense it miles away. If he's out there, we might be able to get a closer look at him. (checks his watch) It's a good time, too. They're night feeders...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see Brody, looking sick and nervous, holding on anxiously as the "Fascinatin' Rhythm" moves slowly ahead trolling at night. His glasses are already flecked with the white salt of dried seawater. He is wearing a life-preserver. Hooper is at the wheel, a chart spread in front of him, his eyes scanning the sea restlessly, checking the dials and gauges in front of him as well as the electronic depth-finding and "fish-finder" gear mounted in the cockpit. A green glow shines from the instruments on his face. Two closed-circuit TV cameras mounted below the hull flash their pictures onto monitors in the dash. In the aisle between the seats is a large container filled with unpleasant-looking bait; Hooper is long-lining for signs of shark, and chumming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody, bored, tired, and slightly queasy, is trying to concentrate on anything but the motion of the boat. He stares at the sophisticated electronics displays.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating distant flashing beacon) That's the Cape Light -- we're on the stretch where he's feeding, if he's still here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is all this stuff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ticking them off) Depth-finder, fathometer, sonar, closed-circuit TV -- fore and aft -- RDF, single side band... (points to themselves) And two loose nuts behind the wheel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you tell from that if a big man- eater is around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes. (indicates display) Look here -- something big, probably a school of mackerel clumped together. And staying right with us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's blipping and peeping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where'd you get all this?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bought it.  Both sets of grandparents set up trust funds for me; stocks went up, so I don't have to touch my principal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're at the Institute full time? Or do you have a job?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a nerve has been touched) It is a job. I'm not fooling around like some amateur. It's my life!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We gotta get back soon...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The two men looking very small and vulnerable in the open sea, the low-hanging mist obscuring their visibility in the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hears something, his eyes widen. It is the "bump-thump" of something scraping the hull.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooper looks up and cuts the wheel hard, as the same time dropping the engines into neutral, and then reverse. The sudden change throws Brody to his knees.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: GARDNER'S BOAT "FLICKA" AWASH AND FLOATING DEAD IN THE SEA

direction.raw_text: : GARDNER'S BOAT "FLICKA" AWASH AND FLOATING DEAD IN THE SEA It's what they've just run into -- flooded to the gunwales, loose debris floating around, a tangle of lines and gear looking like floating garbage in the cockpit. Hooper's light sweeps across it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooper cuts his engines and drifts in; he scampers out to the bow of his boat and makes a line fast to the Flicka.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's Ben Gardner's boat! It's the Flicka! Ben? Ben!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The electronic display is showing increased activity, but only Brody, who is clinging to a support for dear life, can see the blips and hear the chatter. Hooper is leaning out to look at the Flicka.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INSIDE THE COCKPIT OF HOOPER'S BOAT

direction.raw_text: Hooper is examining the Flicka, tying a towline to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: HIS POINT OF VIEW The light picks its way across the ruined boat. The rail where a cleat once was is broadly scarred down to the raw timber, and the heady cleat has been torn bodily out of the hull, ripped out screws and all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something he has seen moves Hooper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sticks his head over the side, into the black water.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to check something. Hold my feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't they have lifejackets or something? An extra boat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surfacing) They must've hit something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: , ELECTRONICS DISPLAY Blip, chatter, blip, chatter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooper moves to get a better look, the boat rocks in the swell and from his movement, Brody clutches the rail in a death-grip. Hooper goes below decks, getting into his wet suit, buckling on a weighted belt, holding a mask and hot flashlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooper takes a last few breaths, orients himself, takes a long, hard look at the quiet, open ocean, and falls into the sea.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He didn't have a dinghy aboard. I'm going down to take a look at his hull.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't we just tow it in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hyperventilating) We will. There's something I've got to find out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be careful, for chrissake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He is studying the surface, trying to follow Hooper's movements. Brody is forcing himself to stay at the edge of the boat by sheer willpower and grim determination. Brody is fascinated by the sea like a bird facing a cobra. He is very much alone. He grasps a flashlight or boathook as a fragile defense against the unknown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beep, chatter, blip.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: PAST BRODY'S BACK TO THE ELECTRONICS

direction.raw_text: SEQUENCE - HOOPER Hooper descends in a froth of bubbles. Warily he turns a full circle with his hotlight. At first we see nothing out of place about the Flicka except that it is lying so low in the water. But as Hooper travels the bottom looking for damage, he comes across a jagged hole two-thirds of the way forward. The hole is about the size of a basketball, and the wood around it has been bashed and splintered. Hooper explores the hole with his hands, then takes the knife from its sheath and begins to dig at something. Whatever it is comes free in his hand. As he studies his find, his light wanders upward, pointing directly into the dark hole. Hooper looks up...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben Gardner's dead face stares out through the hole in the Flicka, eyes and mouth gaping in frozen horror, his skin pinched like a prune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: bumps his head in trying to get away, seems to yell through escaping bubbles. We hear the gasping shout as a bubbling roar in the ears. His mask fills with water as he flails for the surface. Miscalculating, he bumps into the hull of his own boat, shocked, dismayed, his system jangling with adrenaline shock, his hands open, and the object he pried loose from the hull drifts down and out, falling into the eternity of the ocean bottom. He finally bursts through the surface.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SEQUENCE
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is gasping for breath, his whole body vibrating with urgency. The salt water in his lungs combines with the adrenaline in his blood to deprive him of speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooper, despite his shock and surprise, is strangely elated, almost giddy with the wonder of his discovery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody sinks weakly into a chair. Brody huddles in the stern, Hooper kicks the engine in with a roar, and still a-shiver with excitement, turns the boat and its grim tow back to port.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: THE BOAT, HOOPER EMERGING FROM THE WATER

dialogue.raw_text: You all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: White! A Great White, I found a tooth buried in the hull. He must've attacked... I knew it... Gardner's dead in there. I didn't see the mate...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No shark did that to a boat!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus Christ! A Great White! Who'd believe it! We're not talking about a shark, we're talking about a Shark!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Next to the "Amity Welcomes You" billboard is a group of selectmen, Vaughn, Meadows, Hendricks, and another deputy standing by with paint and brushes. Brody's wagon is there, along with a few other cars. Busy late afternoon traffic is starting to pile up as early weekenders and curiosity seekers slow down to see what's happening. Behind the billboard, Brody and Hooper have gotten Vaughn to one side. They are making a closely reasoned presentation to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lost it on the way up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leads Brody around to the front of the billboard, on which we see that some pranksters have painted a huge shark fin in the water behind the swimmer, so she looks now like a frantic bather fleeing a pursuing monster.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There is a kind of shark called a Great White Shark that every expert in the world agrees is a maneater.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're situation here suggests that a Great White has staked out a claim in the waters around Amity Island, and that he will continue to feed here as long as there is food in the water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no limits to where he can strike, and we've had three attacks and two deaths in the past few days. It happened like this before, in 1916, when a Great White killed five swimmers at Jones Beach, in Long Island.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A shark's attack is stimulated by the kind of splashing and activity that occurs whenever humans go swimming -- you can't avoid it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 4th of July beach is like ringing a dinner bell, for Chrissake!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just pulled a shark tooth the size of a shot glass out of the hull of a wrecked boat out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We towed Ben Gardner's boat in, Larry; he was dead and his boat was all chewed up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that tooth here? Did anyone see it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of a shark did you say it was?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Carcaradon carcharias. A Great White.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm not going to commit economic suicide on that flimsy evidence. We depend on the summer people for our lives, and if our beaches are closed, then we're all finished.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have got to close the beaches. We have got to get someone to kill the shark, we need non-corrosive mesh netting, we need scientific support... It's gonna cost money just to keep the nuts out and save what we have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't thing either of you is familiar with our problems...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm familiar with the fact that you are going to ignore this thing until it swims up and bites you on the ass! There are only two ways to solve this thing: you can kill it, or you can cut off its food supply...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That means closing the beaches.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come here, I want to show you something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sick vandalism! Brody, that's a deliberate mutilation of a public service message! I want those little paint-happy bastards caught and hung up by their baby Buster Browns!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (who has followed them around) That's it! I'm standing here arguing with a guy who can't wait to be a hot lunch. Goodbye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute! I need you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Out there is a Perfect Engine, an Eating Machine that is a miracle of evolution -- it swims and eats and that's all. Look at that! Those proportions are correct. (indicates fin) I know sharks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd love to prove that. Getting your name in the National Geographic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Larry, we can re-open the beaches in August.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: August! Tomorrow is the 4th of July, and we are going to open for business. It's going to be our best summer in years. If you're so concerned about the beaches, you two, you do whatever you have to to keep them safe, but with you or without you, the beaches stay open this weekend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Two cavernous iron doors. Then a crack of vertical light as six burly crewmen muscle them apart. The Amity ferry landing is approaching, people in colorful outfits waiting dockside for the first filled-to-capacity shuttle of the summer season and -- Bach's Little Fugue is the musical accompaniment to this wholly visual montage of disembarkation. The next two minutes should be treated like a "short film" taking into account all of the colors, episodes, faces and behavior of a variety of Americans who colonize Eastern resort communities for the ninety-day season. Intercut with this montage is Brody's home, where Ellen, Hooper and Brody are in sweaty, gritty all-out effort to enlist some support. Elements in this montage include: A.  A train of cars trundling down the ramp, bumper to bumper. B.  Young Beautiful People from Princeton, Yale, NYU, wearing knapsacks, toting luggage, babies riding in papoose rigs, energized children, senior citizens holding hands on the pedestrian ramp, a few wheelchairs. C.  Hooper, bent over the phone: "I know it's a long weekend, could you get me his home phone number? D.  Sidewalk vendors hawking "Shark Killed" souvenirs, big photo "Personality Posters" of the dead tiger shark hung on the dock. E.  Brody: "You're acting senior officer? Where's Chief Petty Officer Feldman? Where's the Coast Guard Executive Officer?" F.  Souvenir stands selling Genuine Sharks Teeth from The Amity Killer Shark, Captured This Week. G.  Amity Cab Company, small blue Toyotas lined up with their college student drivers like a bomber wing. H.  Hooper:  "Well then, operator, could you try him in the dining room?" I.  Brody: "All I get is a recording. Is there some other number I could try...?" J.  Station wagons with pale winter faces pressed anxiously to the window. Cadillacs with Rear Admirals at the helm, their wives with blue hair remembering the way from years before. K.  Hooper: "When did he check out? Did he leave another phone number?" L.  Brody: "How can I reach him in Chambers if he's not in Chambers?" M.  Little Karate Hands breaking picket fences. N.  Some local delinquents about 10 or 12 years old, towing behind their bicycles a little dead sand shark with signs: "Amity Monster Shark." "Killed Here." 5 Cents a Hit." Etc. Then six blonde and tanned Coney Island meatballs descend the ramp. They all wear Men's Club Lifeguard patches and matching collegiate windbreakers. They scour the landing, looking for someone to save. The boat is empty. Everybody heading inland, anticipating the best Fourth of July ever. Already there is debris on the docks and the cleaning crew works away at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Bach's Little Fugue ends, the six burly crewmen lean their combined weight against the Cathedral doors, closing out the light and locking in the trade. The doors latch shut with a resounding clang!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is studying everything, trying to make sure he has it covered as well as possible. He almost doesn't hear the approaching roar of a small helicopter until it settles down behind him, and a Flying Officer gets out, starched, pressed fatigues, a flawless fatigue baseball cap, and slick dark aviator's sunglasses. The Steve Canyon of Amity. He presents Brody with a clipboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody signs. The Officer shakes his head as Brody makes an error.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody complies, shaking his head. The Officer snaps him a salute, jogs lightly back to his idling copter, buckles in, and gives Brody a "thumbs up" as he lifts off in a flurry of sand and ice-cream wrappers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Martin Brody? (Brody nods) I'll need your signature here... here... and here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Authorization for direct payment of flight expenses not directly connected to a normal mission of this command. (Brody doesn't understand) You pay for the gas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I signed on the wrong line...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just erase your signature and initial your erasure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: And this is it -- the Dawn Patrol, the only forces that the frantic phone calling produced. Hendricks, and the regular summer extra deputies. The lifeguards. Half a dozen state troopers. Some deputies from neighboring towns, and a Coast Guard ensign with a handful of regulars in work dungarees. Some of Hooper's friends from the institute. Brody and Hooper, badly in need of sleep, are watching the crew straggle in. Already the first of the holiday beach- goers are piling out of their cars in a brightly colored cascade of beach balls, umbrellas, blankets, portable bar-b- ques, radios, sun visors, reflectors, rafts, balls, tubes, and newspapers. Hooper watches one such group: A Family of Ten getting out of a camper-van. He watches in dismay as the family bumbles onto the beach for a day of fun in the sun. Brody addresses his troops, such as they are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Men ad lib responses: "Happy to do it," "Any time," "When's lunch?" "I hate holidays," etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He nods to his men, who head for some Boston Whalers (or similar boat with surf-riding capability) and push off into the surf to patrol the swimming areas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone kind of nods acknowledgment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I want to thank you guys from local agencies for cooperating, and I hope we won't actually be needing your services. But I'm glad to have you here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to get our lines and repellent out, so we better shove off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a last caution) We're all on one channel, so let's keep radio traffic to a minimum, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope we get some more help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish it would rain...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: In a shed near the bandstand, a half-dozen pinball and arcade machines sucking quarters from holiday beach-goers. A mechanical shark traverses the screen, is hit with an electric harpoon and red "blood" blossoms from its side, indicating a hit. Sounds of electronic gadgetry, people having fun. Meadows is there writing it all up for the paper. A move away from the screen of this particular machine reveals the arcade, the parking lot, and, finally, the beginnings of the panorama of the beach that July 4th has created.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: four foot surfer's swell curls and crashes on shore, riderless. The broad sandy beach is a mosaic of summer color as one thousand vacationers practice fun in the sun, but not in the water. Hot dog stands and ice cream vendors are everywhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A half-dozen lookout lofts. As many handsome lifeguards with Walkie-Talkies strapped to their trunks and loud-hailers at arm's reach. Bored, two of the hot dogs train their binoculars on some local color.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mobile Unit Van is setting up: cables snaking to cameras, a camera with a big sports zoom sitting on the platform atop the truck, a spiffy announcer-type in a blazer with his station's call letters on the pocket. Inside the darkened control room, we can see the pale blue squares of monitors in a mosaic against one wall, facing the switcher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooper is methodically patrolling in his boat. Tactically flanking a three-hundred-yard apron of black repellent are four small watch-boats. A tiny pleasure boat darts around the repellent line. Farther out, crossing back and forth, are patrol boats. To top it all off, a Coast Guard helicopter hovers and patrols three hundred feet above.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least eight monitors, reflecting the outputs of three cameras and two tape machines, as well as line, preview, and effects monitors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CAMERA 1: Holding on a group of happy citizen-bathers as they unpack their gear, wave to camera, run into the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CAMERA 2: The Repellent Line, set in place by Coast Guardsmen in small boats, setting out floats, dumping repellent into the ocean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CAMERA 3: Close on the Bandstand, where Amity's band is playing lilting patriotic airs. After we've seen this activity, we can take a look at what's going on: the preparation of the tape segment for the six o'clock news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the "Tape 1" and "Line" monitors, we see Vaughn being interviewed by the Announcer in the blazer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Put 1 on the line. In five. 4. 3. 2. 1. Roll.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and with me is the Mayor of Amity, Lawrence Vaughn. Mr. Vaughn, how about those rumors?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about them indeed. I'm pleased and happy to repeat the news that we have, in fact, caught and killed a large predator that supposedly injured some bathers here. As you can see, it's a beautiful day, the beaches are open, and the folks here are having a wonderful time. Amity, y'know, means 'Friendship.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : CAMERA 1: As Vaughn speaks to us on the monitors, the monitor for Camera 1 pans over to show a Sightseeing Bus pull up in the parking area, and a horde of media vultures spilling out, carrying cameras with long lenses and tripods, telescopes, sunshades and parasols, all the equipment of the curious and none of the equipment of the holiday bather or swimmer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Close on the Announcer, Vaughn out of the picture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hooper's voice fades off as someone at the mixer panel dials his mike off, and brings up the Announcer's lavalier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera pans off him to a happy family headed for the beach.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Also here today is a Marine Biologist and Research Fellow from the Oceanographic Institute, Matthew Hooper. Mr. Hooper, what've you heard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What I've heard and what I've seen are two different things. I believe there is a large Great White Shark -- Carcharodon Cacharias - in the waters off this very beach, that he has killed and that he will kill again...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (moving into center frame) And there you have it -- two different opinions, by men of good will. The holiday crowd here at Amity seems to be making up its own mind...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : CAMERA 3: Zooms in on the puffing face of the tuba player.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : CAMERA 2: Brody and the Announcer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : TAPE 1 and LINE: Back on the Announcer, his lips moving, but his sound turned off. We hear, instead, the sound from Monitor Camera 2, Brody and the same Announcer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, I just don't have the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Recue the machines. 2, pan off the Chief and show me some tits and ass. 1, get me some cute kids. 3... see if you got a shot at the water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : CAMERAS 1, 2 and 3: The cameras seek out the appropriate activity as the Director calls for it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (holds up stopwatch) Mayor, 43 seconds, Biologist 45 seconds. That's equal time, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. (he presses "Talkback" button to his announcer) Jerry, come on in and look at this. (to his headset) Roll 2. In five, 4. 3. 2. 1.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - MONITOR: Starts showing us the assembled interview segment we've just seen, starting with the Announcer's opening remarks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His voice is dialed under as the Announcer himself appears in the control room to watch himself on the monitors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Vaughn begins his spiel again, the other monitors show us the action on the beach.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O. MONITOR) Amity Island is famed for its clear air and white sand beaches. But a cloud appeared...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at that shine on my nose. It's a beacon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Close enough for remote.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...I'm pleased and happy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Think we ought to stick around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What else you got?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Teachers' strike downtown.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Christenson, this is Al. Union says time for Engineering Five.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's five minutes, guys. Coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Vaughn is in his shirtsleeves, having slipped out of his jacket. He mops his brow, and surveys the beachfront. At this moment, there's nobody swimming. He approaches a familiar Selectman, nods hello, and squats beside him on the sand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On an adjoining blanket, a spirited Ruth Gordon type is sitting, watching brightly as her manservant, a polished Eric Harrison type, prepares some tea from a thermos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts down the tea service, and leads her towards the water. At the edge of the sea, she stops, and he walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He ducks his head under for a final look around. His dripping head rises triumphantly from the surf.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts into the water, he takes her parasol, escorting her the rest of the way into the ocean.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you get in the water?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to wash off my suntan lotion. I'll get a burn...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (some urgency) Nobody's going in!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is there nobody going in? What a shame. Arthur, should I be going in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pouring tea) If you'd like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as he enters the waves) It's very nice. Not too cold... Quite refreshing... Very pleasant....
dialogue.name: dialogue
